@graph.name: Frames: Film Notes
@graph.description: Frames helps film photographers log notes, track settings and save EXIF metadata in scanned analog photos. App available for iPhone & Mac.
@graph.keywords: frames,film photography notes,analog notes,film metadata,analog metadata,photo notebook,photo notes,analog photography,film photography,film exif,analog exif,film camera,datafilm

review.name: Just perfect
review.reviewBody: Does all it needs to do in a simple way. It's intuitive, reliable, couldn't ask for more. Thanks for making it free!

review.name: Simple and beautiful
review.reviewBody: The app is simple to use and does what it is supposed to do. I like that you can name the current film rolls as I sometimes forget what I shot with which camera. The UI is simple and just beautiful.

review.name: Great little tool
review.reviewBody: It's a vast improvement over jotting down notes in a notebook be it physical or Apple's built it notes app. Looking forward to future versions!

review.name: Best of it‘s kind
review.reviewBody: Best of all the analog photography metadata apps I have tested so far. It’s simple, it’s fast and yet has all features I need. No ads, no datamining - big plus.

review.name: Amazing app
review.reviewBody: Something good would be to have the shutter speeds in 1/3 steps, since they don't always match the ones used in the shots. Great app!

review.name: My go-to analog photography companion
review.reviewBody: Fantastic tool - simple yet provides all functionality you need to keep track of your rolls. Easy to use in the field, and you get export option to backup your data (or further process it) — well deserved 5 stars!

review.name: This app fills the gap between what digital cameras can do and analog cameras cannot.
review.reviewBody: Lately, film photography has made me feel nostalgic again, and I decided it was time to dive back into it. Unlike back in the day, now—living in the digital age—it’s totally normal to keep track of your shooting data thanks to EXIF metadata. That got me thinking: is there any way to do something similar for photos taken on film? While looking for an answer, I came across this app. With it, you can set up your lens, aperture, and shutter speed in advance, then tap a button each time you take a shot to save those exact settings by frame number. The app also logs the time and GPS location, which gives you a surprisingly detailed record—almost like what you'd get from a digital camera. Of course, there can sometimes be a small difference between the time on your camera and your iPhone, but honestly, it’s barely noticeable and doesn’t really matter for most uses.
